Systems Biology Workbench (SBW)
 PREV CLASS   NEXT CLASS FRAMES    NO FRAMES
SUMMARY:  INNER | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL:  FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

edu.caltech.sbw
Class ModuleImpl

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--edu.caltech.sbw.ModuleImpl
public class ModuleImpl
extends java.lang.Object

The ModuleImpl class is used to define the implementation of a module. Its constructor defines various basic aspects such as the module's name, and the addService(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.Class, java.lang.String) method described below provides the ability to define services associated with the module.

Module Attributes

In addition to services, all module definitions have five pieces of information associated with them: (1) a unique name, (2) a display name, (3) a management type, (4) a class to use as the main class that will be invoked to start up the module, and (5) a help or documentation string. There are several versions of the constructor for ModuleImpl, providing increasingly more control over the definition of the module. The simpler forms derive some of their information dynamically from the Java stack trace at the time the method is called.

Module Management Types

Depending on the kind of services a module implements and the style of use intended, it may be more suitable to have multiple copies (instances) of a module running, or to have only one instance running. Modules that do not keep state information are often best implemented as having only one copy running in an SBW system. For example, a module that performs data conversion operations could run as a unique instance in an SBW system, avoiding the resource usage that would result if a fresh copy were started every time that a client module requested its services.

SBW allows a module developer to designate the type of management that SBW should assume for a module. The type is indicated by a flag to the constructors for the ModuleImpl class.

Using ModuleImpl

The following is an example of the main routine of a very simple module that implements a single service, "Trig". This service is defined by the class Trig (not shown here). 
 package edu.caltech.trigonometry;
 import edu.caltech.sbw;

 class TrigApplication
 {
   public static void main(String[] args)
   {
     try
     {
       ModuleImpl moduleImp = new ModuleImpl("Trigonometry");

       moduleImp.addService("Trig", "sin and cosine functions",
                            "trigonometry", Trig.class);
       moduleImp.run(args);
     }
     catch (SBWException e)
     {
       e.handleWithException();
     }
   }
 }
The creation of a ModuleImpl object is the first step in the definition of the module. The form of the constructor used in this example is a simple one that requires only one argument: a human-readable display name for the module. (See below for other variants of the constructor.) The constructor automatically assigns a unique name to the module based on the package in which the definition is placed (in this case, the unique name becomes *``edu.caltech.trigonometry'').

The first argument of addService(String uniqueName, String displayName, String category, Class implementationClass) is a unique name for the service (unique to the module); the second argument is a short, human-readable display name for the service; the third argument is the service category; and the last argument is the class that implements the service. The class definition is scanned by SBW for public methods, and these become the methods offered by the service. (There exist different variants of the addService(String uniqueName, String displayName, String category, Class implementationClass) method; see below for a list.

The last step is starting up the module. An SBW-enabled application can run in three modes: without SBW, in SBW registration mode, and in module mode. The ModuleImpl class provides a convenience method, run(java.lang.String[]), which takes care of switching between the modes at run time. The determination of which mode to use is made on the basis of a flag passed on the command-line to the application when it is started up. Note the args array passed as an argument to the run(java.lang.String[]) method; this is the array of command-line arguments that was handed to the application's main. If the application is started with the command-line flag -sbwregister, the call to ModuleImpl's run(java.lang.String[]) method registers the module and its services with the SBW Broker and exits; if the application is started with -sbwmodule, it connects to the Broker, notifies it that the module is providing services, and returns, letting the module run until it shuts down or SBW is disconnected. If neither flag is given to the application, run(java.lang.String[]) does nothing.

Field Detail

UNIQUE

public static final int UNIQUE
A module management type that indicates only one module instance will be shared by all applications which access the module and the module will be shut down by SBW.

SELF_MANAGED

public static final int SELF_MANAGED
A module management type that indicates a new module instance will be created every time a module is accessed through SBW.getModuleInstance(java.lang.String) and the module will decide for itself when to shutdown.
Constructor Detail

ModuleImpl

public ModuleImpl(java.lang.String uniqueName,
                  java.lang.String displayName,
                  int type,
                  java.lang.Class moduleMainClass,
                  java.lang.String helpString)
           throws SBWModuleDefinitionException
Defines a new module. The uniqueName is a unique name that identifies this module in SBW. The displayName is a humanly-readable name for the module meant to be used in menus and such. The type code indicates whether the module should be considered SELF_MANAGED or UNIQUE. The class object passed in moduleMainClass is used to determine which class contains the module's main() method and is used to construct a command line for starting up the module. The argument helpString can be used to provide a string that summarizes the purpose of the module; this help string is retrievable by other modules through the SBW Broker.

If the given uniqueName is already known to SBW, the information associated with that module is overwritten by the information supplied in the new call.

The command for starting up the module using the given moduleMainClass has the following generic form:

path-to-java -classpath class-path moduleMainClass -sbwmodule
The classpath is determined from the path to the SBW home directory, and the path to java is the path to the java executable that was used to start this module. To set an explicit command line for starting up the module, use the setCommandLine(java.lang.String) method.

Parameters:
uniqueName - a unique name for the module
displayName - version of the module name intended for human consumption
type - how the module is managed: SELF_MANAGED or UNIQUE
moduleMainClass - the class containing the module's main()
helpString - a string describing the purpose of this module and offering some information about its intended usage
Throws:
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, perhaps because they are null or otherwise unacceptable.

ModuleImpl

public ModuleImpl(java.lang.String uniqueName,
                  java.lang.String displayName,
                  int type,
                  java.lang.Class moduleMainClass)
           throws SBWModuleDefinitionException
Defines a new module. The uniqueName is a unique name that identifies this module in SBW. The displayName is a humanly-readable name for the module meant to be used in menus and such. The type code indicates whether the module should be considered SELF_MANAGED or UNIQUE. The class object passed in moduleMainClass is used to determine which class contains the module's main() method and is used to construct a command line for starting up the module.

This is a shorter version of the constructor ModuleImpl(String uniqueName, String displayName, int type, Class moduleMainClass, String helpString) that does not take a help string; in the present case, the help string is left empty.

If the given uniqueName is already known to SBW, the information associated with that module is overwritten by the information supplied in the new call.

The command for starting up the module using the given moduleMainClass has the following generic form:

path-to-java -classpath class-path moduleMainClass -sbwmodule
The classpath is determined from the path to the SBW home directory, and the path to java is the path to the java executable that was used to start this module. To set an explicit command line for starting up the module, use the setCommandLine(java.lang.String) method.

Parameters:
uniqueName - a unique name for the module
displayName - version of the module name intended for human consumption
type - how the module is managed: SELF_MANAGED or UNIQUE
moduleMainClass - the class containing the module's main()
Throws:
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, perhaps because they are null or otherwise unacceptable.

ModuleImpl

public ModuleImpl(java.lang.String uniqueName,
                  java.lang.String displayName,
                  int type)
           throws SBWModuleDefinitionException
Defines a new module. This is a simplified version of ModuleImpl(String uniqueName, String displayName, int type, Class moduleMainClass, String helpString) that derives some of its arguments from the calling class.

The uniqueName is a unique name that identifies this module in SBW. The displayName is a humanly-readable name for the module meant to be used in menus and such. The type code indicates whether the module should be considered SELF_MANAGED or UNIQUE. The class object is determined automatically from the class in which the constructor is called. This is used to construct a command line for starting up the module.

If the given uniqueName is already known to SBW, the information associated with that module is overwritten by the information supplied in the new call.

Parameters:
uniqueName - a unique name for the module
displayName - version of the module name intended for human consumption
type - how the module is managed: SELF_MANAGED or UNIQUE
moduleMainClass - the class containing the module's main()
Throws:
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, perhaps because they are null or otherwise unacceptable.

ModuleImpl

public ModuleImpl(java.lang.String displayName)
           throws SBWModuleDefinitionException
Defines a new module. This is a simplified version of ModuleImpl(String uniqueName, String displayName, int type, Class moduleMainClass, String helpString) that derives most of its arguments from the calling class. It is intended for quick implementations of modules that are not intended for widespread distribution.

The single argument, displayName, is a humanly-readable name for the module meant to be used in menus and such. The module's unique name is derived from the class object invoking this method (this is obtained by looking through the calling stack). The module's management type is set to SELF_MANAGED. The class that contains the module's main method is assumed to be the calling class. The help string argument of ModuleImpl(String uniqueName, String displayName, int type, Class moduleMainClass, String helpString) is left empty.

If the given uniqueName is already known to SBW, the information associated with that module is overwritten by the information supplied in the new call.

Parameters:
displayName - version of the module name intended for human consumption
Throws:
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, perhaps because they are null or otherwise unacceptable.
See Also:

Method Detail

addService

public void addService(java.lang.String uniqueName,
                       java.lang.String displayName,
                       java.lang.String category,
                       java.lang.Class implementationClass,
                       java.lang.String helpString)
                throws SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException,
                       SBWModuleDefinitionException
Adds a service to the list of services provided by this module. Normally called from a module in register mode. The uniqueName is a unique string that identifies the service; the displayName is a human-readable name, for such uses as displaying in a menu; category is the category into which the service belongs; and implementationClass is the class of the object that implements the service. The argument helpString can be used to provide a string that summarizes the purpose of the service; this help string is retrievable by other modules through the SBW Broker.

If the service is already defined on this module, it is redefined. Equality is determined on the basis of the uniqueName.

Parameters:
uniqueName - a unique name for the service
displayName - version of the service name intended for human consumption
category - the category into which to place the service
implementationClass - the class of the object that implements the service.
helpString - a string describing the purpose of this service and perhaps offering some information about its intended usage
Throws:
SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException - if the syntax of the category name is invalid
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, for example by being null or otherwise unacceptable.

addService

public void addService(java.lang.String uniqueName,
                       java.lang.String displayName,
                       java.lang.String category,
                       java.lang.Object implementationObject,
                       java.lang.String helpString)
                throws SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException,
                       SBWModuleDefinitionException
Adds a service to the list of services provided by this module. Normally called from a module in register mode. The uniqueName is a unique string that identifies the service; the displayName is a human-readable name, for such uses as displaying in a menu; category is the category into which the service belongs; and implementationObject is an instance of the object that implements the service. The argument helpString can be used to provide a string that summarizes the purpose of the service; this help string is retrievable by other modules through the SBW Broker.

If the service is already defined on this module, it is redefined. Equality is determined on the basis of the uniqueName.

Parameters:
uniqueName - a unique name for the service
displayName - version of the service name intended for human consumption
category - the category into which to place the service
implementationObject - an instance of the object that implements the service.
helpString - a string describing the purpose of this service and perhaps offering some information about its intended usage
Throws:
SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException - if the syntax of the category name is invalid
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, for example by being null or otherwise unacceptable.

In this version of the method, the help string that is accepted by addService(String uniqueName, String displayName, String category, Class implementationClass, String helpString) is set to the empty string.

addService

public void addService(java.lang.String uniqueName,
                       java.lang.String category,
                       java.lang.Object implementationObject)
                throws SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException,
                       SBWModuleDefinitionException
Adds a service to the list of services provided by this module. Normally called from a module in register mode. This is a variant method in which the unique name and display name are set to the same string, the given uniqueName. Parameter category is the category into which the service belongs, and implementationObject is an instance of the object that implements the service.

In this version of the method, the help string that is accepted by addService(String uniqueName, String displayName, String category, Object implementationObject, String helpString) is set to the empty string.

If the service is already defined on this module, it is redefined. Equality is determined on the basis of the uniqueName.

Parameters:
uniqueName - a unique name for the service; this is also used for the display name
category - the category into which to place the service
implementationObject - an instance of the object that implements the service.
Throws:
SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException - if the syntax of the category name is invalid
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, for example by being null or otherwise unacceptable.

addService

public void addService(java.lang.String uniqueName,
                       java.lang.String category,
                       java.lang.Class implementationClass)
                throws SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException,
                       SBWModuleDefinitionException
Adds a service to the list of services provided by this module. Normally called from a module in register mode. This is a variant method in which the unique name and display name are set to the same string, the given uniqueName. Parameter category is the category into which the service belongs, and implementationClass is the class of object that implements the service.

In this version of the method, the help string that is accepted by addService(String uniqueName, String displayName, String category, Class implementationClass, String helpString) is set to the empty string.

If the service is already defined on this module, it is redefined. Equality is determined on the basis of the uniqueName.

Parameters:
uniqueName - a unique name for the service; this is also used for the display name
category - the category into which to place the service
implementationClass - the class of object that implements the service.
Throws:
SBWIncorrectCategorySyntaxException - if the syntax of the category name is invalid
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if any of the arguments are invalid, for example by being null or otherwise unacceptable.

registerModule

public void registerModule()
                    throws SBWModuleDefinitionException,
                           SBWBrokerStartException,
                           SBWCommunicationException
Connects to the SBW Broker running on the local computer, sends the registration information for this module and its defined services, then returns.

Note that simply creating a ModuleImpl(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, int, java.lang.Class, java.lang.String) object with one of the constructors does not actually define the module to the SBW Broker. It is not until either of the methods registerModule() or enableModuleServices() are called that SBW contacts the Broker.

Throws:
SBWCommunicationException - if there is a problem communicating with the SBW Broker
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if the SBW Broker determines there is something wrong with the module definition.

enableModuleServices

public void enableModuleServices()
                          throws SBWCommunicationException,
                                 SBWBrokerStartException
Whereas the registerModule() method registers the module with the SBW Broker and returns, the enableModuleServices() notifies the Broker that the module is now able to receive calls.

Throws:
SBWCommunicationException - if there is a problem communicating with the SBW Broker

setCommandLine

public void setCommandLine(java.lang.String cmdline)
Sets a specific command line for starting up this module. The default command for starting up the module is based on the main class given to the constructor method ModuleImpl(String uniqueName, String displayName, int type, Class moduleMainClass). The default has the following generic form:
path-to-java -classpath class-path moduleMainClass -sbwmodule
The classpath is determined from the path to the SBW home directory, and the path to java is the path to the java executable that was used to start this module.

The setCommandLine(java.lang.String) method gives complete control over the command line that should be used to start up this module. The command supplied must include the path to the java executable and the -sbwmodule argument.

Note that no verification is performed on the validity of the given command line. SBW and client modules will not learn whether the given command line correctly starts up the module until the next time that SBW attempts to run it.

Parameters:
cmdline - the explicit command line to use to start up this module

getCommandLine

public java.lang.String getCommandLine()
Returns the command line set for this module implementation.

Returns:
a string, the command line for this module
See Also:
setCommandLine(java.lang.String)

run

public void run(java.lang.String[] args)
         throws SBWModuleDefinitionException,
                SBWCommunicationException,
                SBWBrokerStartException
Convenience function for performing the tasks required for handling the -sbwregister and -sbwmodule options to a module. This method must be passed the array of command-line arguments passed to the application. This then checks for the presence of -sbwregister and -sbwmodule, and acts as follows:
  • If the flag -sbwregister is found first in the array of command-line arguments given to the program, this method invokes the registerModule() method followed by Java's System.exit(int) call.

  • If the flag -sbwmodule is found first in the array of command-line arguments, this method invokes enableModuleServices() and returns.

The calling routine should perform whatever tasks it would after enabling module services. Most modules will not need to perform anything else and should simply return.

The exceptions thrown by this method are simply propagated from the calls to registerModule() and enableModuleServices().

Parameters:
args - the array of strings passed to the main method of the application
Throws:
SBWCommunicationException - if there is a problem communicating with the SBW Broker
SBWModuleDefinitionException - if the SBW Broker determines there is something wrong with the module definition.
